timeline.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText:
I am thinking, now that we have authProvider, why not make only requestProcessor take email, userID and auth from that interface.
Also noticed that

public method only takes token.
we already have email, userId set before calling registerForPush

Although not sure why the line 435 method is protected.
replies.author: Ayyanchira

replies.bodyText:
Hmm.. we should have regression tests for these. Basically, the reason we're passing email, userId and authToken here is because getting a token is asynchronous. By the time we get the token, the user identifiers might've changed.
Example:

You set email to null
It calls disableDevice to disable the token for the logged out user
If we pass the current email/userId/authToken and then set email to null, we'll be able to call disableDevice with old auth even though the current one is all null
If we don't store the auth with the token request, it will get the current auth info from authProvider, which is already null, and will fail to disable the device.
replies.author: vbabenkoru

timeline.bodyText: Do we need to create the request processor every time?
timeline.author: vbabenkoru

replies.bodyText: For now... Once we take parameters from config whether its online or offline, apiclient can create corresponding global request processor.
replies.author: Ayyanchira

timeline.message:
[MOB-2002] - Request Processor - Online

1. Introduced RequestProcessor interface
2. Implemented OnlineRequestProcessor which now creates IterableRequest and executes it
3. emails, userIds and authToken is now mainly fetched from authProvider from apiClient
4. changed/removed method signature for internal methods which had authToken or passed emailId or userId around
5  Changed IterablePushRegistration classes to accomodate authHandler changes
6. Changes in test method to make it pass.
